Description: Body sherd of Attic black-figured pottery open vessel, possibly a dinos; interior glazed (fired brownish-red); exterior: black-figure decoration consisting of frontal chariot (part of chariot, axle and wheel with added red, breast and forelegs of left yoke horse with elaborate harmess and, to right, leg of trace horse).
Curator's comments: Object owned and held by the Fitzwilliam Museum, Cambridge. This record is included in the British Museum database as part of the Museum’s Naukratis Project, a research collaboration that aims to virtually re-unite finds from the ancient port city of Naukratis, now distributed over 80 museums worldwide.

Beazley compares the dinos Louvre E873 (ABV, 1956, 39, no. 14). See also Moore (1972) 'Horses on black-figured Greek vases of the archaic period', p.26, no.A87 and Bakir (1981) 'Sophilos', p.66, no.A6
Bibliographic references: CVA Cambridge II / Corpus Vasorum Antiquorum: Great Britain, Fascicule 11, Cambridge, Fascicule 2 (p. 42, pl. XXI, no. 33)
Venit 1982 / Painted Pottery from the Greek Mainland found in Egypt, 640-450 BC (p. 292, no. B273)
Villing et al 2013-2015 / Naukratis: Greeks in Egypt (GA.1197)
